{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3387675,"name":"Jason Daming","username":"jdaming","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jdaming/{size}/137720_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-17T16:05:44.162Z","cooked":"

It was great to see everyone at Championship. I hope you got a chance to stop by the WPILib booth to talk with us and get some swag. Here is a summary of the top priorities for things we would like to work on. No guarantees that all of these will make it for 2025, and we would really appreciate any community assistance! Please see the roadmap slides below for more detail:

  • Change the command structure relating to auto and triggers
  • Add the ability to optionally clear deploy folders
  • Bring Elastic into the library and update dashboard configuration
  • Improved vendordep experience. Improved installer supporting outside tools.
  • Better data logging and unified telemetry (Sendable rewrite, telemetry, annotations)

Conferences:
WPILib Roadmap - Slides
Unexplored Features in WPILib - Slides
AdvantageScope and AdvantageKit
RobotPy: past, present, and future - Slides
WPILib Feedback and Open Q&A - This wasn’t recorded and there were no slides. Thanks to NI, REV, and CTRE for lending their expertise for the panel.

Also posted on the WPILib Blog

Some of the projects mentioned in the roadmap are already in progress or experimentation. Here are a few that I’ve been focusing on, and as always, feedback is greatly appreciated.

Annotation-based logging

Using custom annotations and an annotation processor to generate custom data loggers for user code at compile time. The barrier to entry is about as low as it can feasibly be; just add a @Logged annotation to any class you want to be logged and add Epilogue.bind(this) in robotInit() to start logging to NT.

github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib

Add an annotation-based logging framework for Java programs

wpilibsuite:main ← SamCarlberg:annotation-logging
opened 05:23PM - 04 May 24 UTC
SamCarlberg
+5147 -7

An annotation processor will generate data loggers at compile time based on the …contents of the annotated classes. Logging is opt-out by default; placing an `@Logged` annotation on a class will attempt to log *everything* in that class. This can be configured by setting the strategy on the class and by configuring the importance levels on the logged elements, or by placing a `@NotLogged` annotation on fields and methods that should always be excluded Explicitly tagging a non-loggable element will result in a compile-time error Data is logged to NetworkTables by default, but can be configured to use any backend (just implement the `DataLogger` interface) ~~This relies on features added between Java 11 and 17, including text blocks and pattern matching, and I've included a small commit that bumps our source compatibility. We already build with and ship JDK 17 to teams, so this is just giving us access to those language features.~~ Added separately in #6585

Coroutine commands

Tentatively scheduled for 2027, this is highly experimental and still in the design phase. It allows commands to be implemented with a single function instead of needing separate functions for init, loop execution, completion checks, and cleanup. Notably, this can massively simplify dynamic autonomous routines:

AsyncCommand dynamicAuto() {
  return AsyncCommand.requiring(drive, intake, shooter).run(() -> {
    drive.driveToDecisionPoint();
    intake.deploy();
    if (vision.isPreferredNoteAvailable()) {
      drive.driveToPreferredNote();
    } else {
      drive.driveToFallbackNote();
    }
    intake.retract();
    drive.driveToSubwoofer();
    shooter.shoot();
  }).named("Dynamic Auto");
}

(exact naming is still TBD)

This is a from-scratch reimplementation of commands and also introduces many small improvements like command prioritization, suspend-on-interrupt, and smarter scheduler logic that better tracks composed commands and nested subsystems. Most of those can be backported to the current commands framework, and some (like priorities) are already being added.

github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib

[DRAFT] Add async command framework using Java 21 language features

wpilibsuite:main ← SamCarlberg:better-async-commands
opened 12:41AM - 17 Apr 24 UTC
SamCarlberg
+5394 -9

There's a lot of WIP code in here that needs to be cleaned up. I'm opening th…is PR anyway to get eyes on this and start a discussion. The framework fundamentally relies on virtual threads added in Java 21; in addition, parallel command groups rely on the structured concurrency API added as a preview feature in Java 21 (which is also in a second preview in Java 22). Configuring the JVM to use a single carrier thread for all virtual threads in the process means async commands and triggers can be written without needing multithreaded concepts like locks and atomic field access. The async framework allows command bodies to be written in an imperative style: ```java HardwareResource drivetrain = new Drivetrain(); AsyncCommand driveTenFeet = drivetrain.run(() -> { drivetrain.resetEncoders(); while (drivetrain.getDistance() < 10) { AsyncCommand.pause(); // <- note the pause call! drivetrain.tankDrive(1, 1); } drivetrain.stop(); }).named("Drive Ten Feet"); ``` Which would look something like this using the current functional framework: ```java Subsystem drivetrain = new Drivetrain(); Comand driveTenFeet = drivetrain.runOnce(drivetrain::resetEncoders) .andThen(driveTrain.run(() -> drivetrain.tankDrive(1, 1)) .until(() -> drivetrain.getDistance() < 10) .finallyDo(drivetrain::stop) .withName("Drive Ten Feet"); ``` Commands could be written as thin wrappers around regular imperative methods: ```java class Drivetrain extends HardwareResource { void driveDistance(Measure<Distance> distance) { encoders.reset(); while (getDistance().lt(distance)) { AsyncCommand.pause(); tankDrive(1, 1); } stop(); } AsyncCommand driveDistanceCommand(Measure<Distance> distance) { return run(() -> driveDistance(distance)).named("Drive " + distance.in(Feet) + " Feet"); } } ``` However, an async command *will* need to be *actively* cooperative and periodically call blocking operations for the virtual thread that executes it to be paused and allow another vthread to be scheduled. This can be accomplished by calling `AsyncCommand.pause()` in every loop run, which just calls `Thread.sleep(20)` under the hood to pause the vthread for 20 milliseconds. Calling `AsyncCommand.pause(Measure)` allows for custom pause times, such as 5 or 10 milliseconds for commands that require tighter loops. Operations that pause the current thread (such as calling `.get` on a future or acquiring a read/write lock) will allow for a vthread to be parked and another vthread to be continued. `synchronized` blocks and methods do *not* pause the vthread, and will instead block the native *carrier thread*, and thus *all commands and triggers* as well. In addition, virtual threads cannot be paused while executing in native code. There are also some other additions like priority levels (as opposed to a blanket yes/no for ignoring incoming commands), factories requiring names be provided for commands, and the scheduler tracking all running commands and not just the highest-level groups. However, those changes aren't unique to an async framework, and could just as easily be used in a traditional command framework. Links: [JEP 425 - Virtual Threads](https://openjdk.org/jeps/425) [JEP 453 - Structured Concurrency](https://openjdk.org/jeps/453) [The async version of the rapid react example project](https://github.com/SamCarlberg/allwpilib/tree/better-async-commands/wpilibjExamples/src/main/java/edu/wpi/first/wpilibj/examples/async/) [AsyncScheduler.java](https://github.com/SamCarlberg/allwpilib/blob/better-async-commands/wpilibNewCommands/src/main/java/edu/wpi/first/wpilibj3/command/async/AsyncScheduler.java) [ParallelGroup.java](https://github.com/SamCarlberg/allwpilib/blob/better-async-commands/wpilibNewCommands/src/main/java/edu/wpi/first/wpilibj3/command/async/ParallelGroup.java) [Sequence.java](https://github.com/SamCarlberg/allwpilib/blob/better-async-commands/wpilibNewCommands/src/main/java/edu/wpi/first/wpilibj3/command/async/Sequence.java)

LED animation API

Not part of the larger roadmap, this was something that I wrote for my team this season and thought would be useful to upstream. You can check out the example code (and GIFs!) in the PR. Some people here on CD have already found it and seem to be enjoying it

github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib

Add LED pattern API for easily animating addressable LEDs

wpilibsuite:development ← SamCarlberg:led-patterns
opened 08:32PM - 04 Feb 24 UTC
SamCarlberg
+2104 -241

Add LEDReader and LEDWriter helper interfaces to facilitate composing simple pat…terns into more complex ones, e.g. `LEDPattern.solid(Color.kBlue).breathe(Seconds.of(0.75))`. Pattern composition relies on changing out the write behavior; for example, `offsetBy` increments the indexes to write to; while `blink` will switch between playing a base pattern and turning off all the LEDs. Add a view class for splitting a single large buffer into smaller distinct sections, which is useful for dealing with long chained LED strips mounted on different parts of a robot. Views cannot be written directly to an LED strip (in fact, trying to do so won't even compile) Adds some utility methods to the `Color` class for interpolating between two colors, and support color representations with 32-bit integers to avoid object allocations ## Examples Command based subsystem: ```java class LEDs extends SubsystemBase { private final AddressableLED m_led; private final AddressableLEDBuffer m_ledData; private final AddressableLEDBufferView m_leftSide; private final AddressableLEDBufferView m_rightSide; public LEDs() { m_led = new AddressableLED(9); m_led.setLength(120); m_ledData = new AddressableLEDBuffer(120); m_leftSide = m_ledData.createView(0, 59); m_rightSide = m_ledData.createView(60, 119).reversed(); } @Override public void periodic() { m_led.writeData(m_ledData); } public Command runAnimation(LEDPattern animation) { return run(() -> { animation.applyTo(m_leftSide); animation.applyTo(m_rightSide); }); } } ``` Animated rainbow: ```java LEDPattern rainbow = LEDPattern.rainbow(255, 255).scrollAtRelativeSpeed(Percent.per(Second).of(50)); ``` ![rainbow](https://github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib/assets/6320992/eb24a655-ad8c-4100-9953-5c33d97563a9) Flag: ```java LEDPattern canada = LEDPattern.steps(Map.of(0, Color.kRed, 1 / 3.0, Color.kWhite, 2 / 3.0, Color.kRed)); LEDPattern canadaScroll = canada.scrollAtRelativeSpeed(Percent.per(Second).of(33)); ``` <img width="786" alt="image" src="https://github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib/assets/6320992/caa55aec-baad-4821-83e8-73142d452623"> ![canadascroll](https://github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib/assets/6320992/417d7866-0d9b-4e7e-98ed-dc85eae60c06) Playing animations for an alliance color based on driverstation data: ```java LEDPattern breatheBlue = LEDPattern.solid(Color.kFirstBlue).breathe(Seconds.of(2)); LEDPattern breatheRed = LEDPattern.solid(Color.kFirstRed).breathe(Seconds.of(2)); LEDPattern flashYellow = LEDPattern.solid(Color.kYellow).blink(Seconds.of(0.5)); LEDPattern allianceColor = (read, write) -> { LEDPattern alliancePattern; if (Driverstation.getAlliance().isPresent()) { if (Driverstation.getAlliance.get() == Driverstation.Alliance.Blue) { alliancePattern = breatheBlue; } else { alliancePattern = breatheRed; } } else { alliancePattern = flashYellow; } alliancePattern.applyTo(read, write); }; ``` ![alliancecolors](https://github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib/assets/6320992/d6c607ed-857b-475b-b0e4-5acd31029fab)

SamCarlberg:

Annotation-based logging

Using custom annotations and an annotation processor to generate custom data loggers for user code at compile time. The barrier to entry is about as low as it can feasibly be; just add a @Logged annotation to any class you want to be logged and add Epilogue.bind(this) in robotInit() to start logging to NT.

I am super thrilled to see this finally come standard as part of WPILib. It makes a huge difference when doing rapid development, in my experience.

The implementation is sweet, too.

The main thing is to look at all the things GradleRIO (and deploy-utils) has to do for deployment:

  • Target discovery (both team number driven and getting the target IP from the DS). This needs to include checking the image version for Rio targets.
  • Deployment via SSH of different types of artifacts (e.g. libraries, executables, command scripts, file trees). Some of these need synchronization type capabilities to avoid unnecessary copies (e.g. checksum both sides and/or grab a checksum file from the target and compare)
  • Running commands (also via SSH) to set permissions, etc, including support for arbitrary commands
  • Running a detection script (e.g. checking remote JDK version) and running actions depending on the result (e.g. deploying/installing a different JDK)

Writing down what the requirements are and spec’ing out the JSON file and command line arguments should be the first step. There’s lots of decisionables here; to name a few:

  • Should the team number be a command line argument, pulled from a local config file, or both (e.g. pulled from a local config file, but can be overridden from the command line)? What about supporting coprocessors with arbitrary IPs?
  • Should the JSON only allow pointing to actual files (and any extraction, e.g. from Maven artifacts, be done by the build system), or should the deploy tool have integrated support for downloading and/or extract things before deploy?
  • Is the JSON file describing a sequence of configurable steps, or more of a functional description (e.g. here’s the libraries, here’s the executables, etc), or some combination of those two things? For coprocessors, custom steps is great, but for Rio type deploys, we want to minimize the chance of build system errors messing up deploy sequences, so there’s a tension there.

SamCarlberg:

Coroutine commands

Tentatively scheduled for 2027, this is highly experimental and still in the design phase. It allows commands to be implemented with a single function instead of needing separate functions for init, loop execution, completion checks, and cleanup. Notably, this can massively simplify dynamic autonomous routines:

There’s 2 paradigms I’ve always wanted to see with coroutines in WPILib. The following examples are in no particular language

  1. Awaitable commands or boolean predicates. And the ability to mix old-style and new-style commands. I used await here which python has. C++ has co_await, I’m not sure what Java has.
placeConeHigh() {
  await setElevator(HIGH);  // suspends until command completes
  await extendArm();  // suspends until command completes
  openClaw();  // normal synchronous method
  await Time(0.5s);  // waits half a second
  ...
}
  1. Asynchronous periodic commands, similar to what you’re already proposing
driveToPose(target) {
  // initialize stuff
  controller.setGoal(target);
  // loop executes every 20ms, ends when command is cancelled
  // or on predicate, or when the loop is broken out of for any reason
  while (every(20ms).cancellable().until(() -> {return isCloseEnough(target)})) 
  {
    drive(controller.calculate(getPose());
  }

  // stop
  drive({0, 0, 0});
}

On a separate note, would it even be possible to have this with C++20 coroutines. I believe a special compiler flag has to be enabled (-fcoroutines), not sure if the frc compiler has support for that.

I guess you said this is planned for 2027, so we don’t even know what the compiler will be…

Managed to implement AdvantageKit lite (logging of IO with replay) this year in C++ by just having a templated “Logged” class that serves as a wrapper on an IO input getter and holds a reference to a LogHelper that determines if the data should be logged or replayed. Very basic and a far cry from the annotation joy suggested but even a more awkward solution goes a long way compared to no solution.

bathtubed:

On a separate note, would it even be possible to have this with C++20 coroutines. I believe a special compiler flag has to be enabled (-fcoroutines), not sure if the frc compiler has support for that.

There is no special compiler used for FRC, if the compiler on your system supports coroutines normally it will for FRC as well. The flag can just be added to the default arguments if WPILib needs it.
